questions.text: Identify the bacteria that causes the phenomenon shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The given picture shows swarming, which is exhibited by Proteus.

Proteus species move very actively by means of peritrichous flagella, resulting in “swarming” on solid media. It can be suppressed by

  • Phenylethyl alcohol
  • Cystine-lactose-electrolyte-deficient (CLED) medium

Other organisms that show swarming include:

  • Clostridium tetani
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Serratia

questions.text: In a population of 5000, the birth rate is 30 per 1000 population. 15 children died in their first year of life and of those 9 died in their first month. What is the infant mortality rate in this population:
questions.solution:
• Infant mortality rate (IMR) = (Number of deaths of children under age 1 in a year x 1000) / (Number of live births in that year)
  • In this scenario, the number of live births would be 150.( i.e, birth rate is 30 per 1000 population ; total population is 5000 ; therefore total birth rate is 30/ 1000 × 5000 = 150 )
  • Number of deaths of children under age 1 is 15
  • IMR = 100
  • IMR is regarded as the most important indicator of the health status of a community and of the effectiveness of MCH care
  • As of SRS bulletin 2018, Indian IMR is 32

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presents with pain around his knee. His X-Ray is as given below.  Which of the following statements is correct about the condition?

choices.text: Always seen before the closure of nearby physis

questions.solution:
X-ray shows expansile, eccentric, sub-articular soap bubble appearance lesion suggestive of Giant cell tumor (Osteoclastoma). The tumor, indeed, has the potential to transform into osteosarcoma.

Other options:

GCT is rarely seen before the closure of nearby physis and usually extends upto the nearby subarticular bone plate.

The typical presentation is that of a young adult with a painful swelling at the end of a long bone, although, there may be no swelling at times.

GCT is seen most commonly in the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus, and distal radius. Not just in the lower limb.

The treatment for GCT is extended curettage and resection if residual bone stock is inadequate.

questions.text: Inheritance pattern depicted in the following pedigree chart is:
questions.solution:
In the given pedigree chart females are carriers and only males are affected and males pass it on to all female progenies but not any male progeny. Hence it is X linked disorder.

Since disease is not manifesting in carrier females, it is a recessive disorder.

Hence this is an X linked recessive inheritance.

questions.text: In the following LV pressure-volume loop diagram, the mitral valve will close at point ______
questions.solution:
The mitral valve will close at point B.

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml, called the end-diastolic volume and the diastolic pressure rising to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

During isovolumic contraction, the volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. The line labeled “IV” traces this decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled “EW”) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following DPP4 inhibitors can be given in a patient with renal failure without dose adjustment?
questions.solution:
Linagliptin can be safely used in renal failure as it is mainly excreted through hepatobiliary route.

DPP4 inhibitors are orally acting novel drugs which act by the incretin pathway and stimulate insulin secretion. These drugs have significant lesser chances of hypoglycemic side effects. These drugs are mainly eliminated unchanged by the kidneys except Linagliptin which is eliminated by the hepatobiliary route and therefore are considered relatively safer in a patient with renal failure.

questions.text: The patient whose hands are shown in the image below is developmentally delayed with a short, stocky build. Which of the following laboratory values is consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the history and the appearance the most likely diagnosis is pseudohypoparathyroidism. The deformity of the hands shown in the image is due to short metacarpals. Other deformities include short metatarsals, round facies, and thickening of the calvarium.

  • The syndrome is caused by target organ unresponsiveness to PTH, and was the first hormone resistance syndrome described.
  • The findings of hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia are the same as in hypoparathyroidism, but the serum PTH levels are appropriately increased.
  • The hypocalcemia is due to a deficient response to PTH, which is probably restricted to the proximal renal tubules. Hyperplasia of the parathyroids, a response to hormone resistanthypocalcemia, causes elevation of PTH levels.
  • The normal urinary rise in cAMP does not occur when these patients are injected with exogenous (normal) PTH.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male came to the hospital with complaints of diplopia, and progressive headache. Examination of extraocular movements revealed the findings as shown in the image, when the patient attempted to look right. Lesion involving which cranial nerve marked in the image below is likely to cause the condition, and which eye is affected?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding shown in the image is suggestive of lateral rectus palsy of the right eye, which occurs due to the lesion involving right abducens nerve. In the given image, showing the base of the brain, the right abducens nerve is marked as ‘3’.

The Abducens nerve arises from the brainstem between the pons and medulla oblongata. It enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure and innervates the lateral rectus muscle through its medial (ocular surface).

Determining the palsy:

The abduction and adduction of the eye are caused by the action of the lateral rectus and medial rectus muscles respectively.

The lateral rectus is innervated by abducens nerve (VI) while the medial rectus is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (III).

Horizontal conjugate movements occur when both eyes moves horizontally to look right or left.

  • In right gaze: The right eye abducts and the left eye adducts.
  • In left gaze: The right eye adducts and the left eye abducts.

In the image, when the patient attempted to look right, the left eye adducted normally, while the right eye failed to abduct. This is suggestive of right lateral rectus palsy due to the lesion involving the right abducens nerve.

Note: If the same finding as shown in the image is seen when the patient is looking straight (neutral gaze), then the affected eye is the left eye. In such case, due to left lateral rectus palsy, the action of left medial rectus is unopposed causing adduction of the left eye.

questions.text: Risk of tubal pregnancy is increased by all except?
questions.solution:
Oral combined pill use does not increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy. In fact, combined pills reduce the risk of ectopic pregnancy.

An ectopic pregnancy is one in which the fertilized ovum is implanted and develops outside the normal endometrial cavity, with the Fallopian tubes being the most common site. The outcomes of such a pregnancy are varied with tubal rupture and massive intraperitoneal hemorrhage being one of them.

Risk factors of ectopic pregnancy:

  • Previous ectopic pregnancy
  • Tubal corrective surgery, tubectomy
  • IUCD
  • Assisted reproductive technology
  • Documented tubal pathology
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (Chlamydia infection and salpingitis isthmica nodosa)
  • Genital tuberculosis
  • Endometriosis
  • Pelvic adhesions
  • Congenital elongation, accessory ostia, diverticula
  • Transmigration
  • Smoking
  • Prior abortion
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Prior Caesarean delivery
  • Progesterone-only pills (POPs)

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with fissured tongue and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from riboflavin/vitamin B2 deficiency.

Deficiency of riboflavin is characterized by cheilosis, desquamation, and inflammation of the tongue, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, anemia, and personality changes.

Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the ER with headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. A CT of the head is shown below. Physical examination shows positive Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs. Vitals: Temp: 101 F, BP: 120/88 mmHg, PR: 110 beats/min, pupils reactive. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is surgical clipping.
CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space. This is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.
SAH can present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Other options:

  1. IV Ceftriaxone: Vancomycin + ceftriaxone is the recommended therapy for bacterial meningitis. Meningitis does not show hyper-attenuated subarachnoid space.
  2. IV Tenecteplase: Used for ischemic stroke without bleeding complications.
  3. Aspirin: Used for acute ischemic stroke when fibrinolysis is contraindicated

 

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: Abnormalities related to P300 evoked potential on EEG is reported in which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
An abnormal ‘P300’ evoked potential is seen in schizophrenia.

Abnormalities related to the following evoked potentials may be seen on EEG in patients with schizophrenia,

  • P300: It is a large, positive wave which occurs 300 mil­liseconds after a sensory stimulus is detected.
  • N100: It is a negative wave that occurs 100 milliseconds after a stimulus.
  • Contingent negative variation: It is a slow developing negative wave that occurs after a stimulus and serves as a warning for an upcoming stimulus.

questions.text: The mother of a newborn in your unit is extremely sick and is unable to feed her baby. The relatives have arranged a breast milk donor and wish to feed the baby using the device shown in the image. This method of primary feeding can be recommended in newborns with a gestational age of _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks only. Sick mothers or mothers with contraindications to breastfeeding can feed their child using paladai. The milk can either be expressed breastmilk or they can resort to using undiluted cow milk or formula feeds. 

<32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai can only be used occasionally.

>34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern when breastfeeding becomes more preferred.

questions.text: A person knows the truth and willfully conceals the truth and instead gives false evidence in the court of law. He will be punished under which IPC
questions.solution:
The person in the above situation has committed perjury.

Section 193 IPC deals with Punishment for giving or fabricating false evidence in judicial proceeding or in any other case.
